--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> I want to make a comment on the discussion about
> speciation.  We all agree that our field is inspired
> by, and largely patterned after, what we know about
> biology.  When thinking about this we often think
> about the creatures we are most familiar with,
> namely,homo sapiens.  
> In my opinion it is more fruitful to
> think about much simpler organisms, such as
> bacteria,
> yeast, algae, etc.  Even those are much more
> complicated than our models, but they are closer,
> since we don't have sexual reproduction, nor many
> other genetic & developmental phenomena found in
> nature.  So I think we should model our work after
> the
> simplest organisms that we know something about.

Well, but NEAT does employ sexual reproduction, albeit
a very simplified representation of it, which is
obviously a more complicated mode of reproduction than
asexual reproduction.

If we only used the simplest models from nature, then
we would be potentially excluding some of the most
effective evolutionary features.

You're right that we should keep in mind that our
models are nowhere near the complexity of biological
ones, and so analogy with real-world organisms
sometimes breaks down.  But if we're modeling sexual
reproduction, obviously we need to draw analogies from
organisms that actually reproduce that way.

Derek
